What is Leicester famous for?

Leicester is a city that is famous for many things, such as its history, culture, diversity and sports. Here are some of the highlights of what Leicester has to offer:

Leicester is home to the remains of King Richard III, who was killed at the Battle of Bosworth in 1485 and buried in a medieval friary. His skeleton was discovered in 2012 under a car park and reburied in Leicester Cathedral in 2015. You can learn more about his life and death at the King Richard III Visitor Centre.

Leicester is also known for its multiculturalism, as it has one of the most diverse populations in the UK. You can experience the rich variety of cultures, cuisines and festivals in Leicester, such as the Diwali celebrations, which are the largest outside India. You can also visit the Golden Mile, a street full of Indian shops, restaurants and jewellery stores.

Leicester is a city that loves sports, especially football and rugby. You can watch Leicester City Football Club, who won the Premier League title in 2016, at the King Power Stadium. You can also cheer for Leicester Tigers Rugby Club, who are one of the most successful teams in England, at the Welford Road Stadium.

Leicester is a city that embraces art and creativity, with many museums, galleries and theatres to explore. You can visit the New Walk Museum and Art Gallery, which has collections of natural history, fine art and ancient Egypt. You can also see contemporary art at the Attenborough Arts Centre, which was founded by Sir David Attenborough. You can also catch a show at the Curve Theatre, which is a state-of-the-art venue for musicals, dramas and comedies.
